awd_titl_txt: Workshop:  Recruiting and Retaining Faculty of Color
awd_abstract_narration:
This workshop features senior scholars of color sharing their expertise on recruiting and retaining faculty of color at the department level, the college level, and the institutional level.  The workshop has three tangible outcomes: 1) To educate search committees on the best practices of recruiting and retaining faculty of color. 2) To educate college leaders on why faculty of color leave, and how to create campuses that welcome faculty of color, and 3) To identify specific institutional changes college leaders may make to ensure the faculty body reflects the student body.  The workshop will be of interest to department chairs, search committee chairs, and campus trustees.  In order to maximize attendance, the workshop is being held at the Annual Meeting of the American Political Science Association.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Higher Ed institutions share the goal of diversifying the professoriate.  The value of diversity and difference to the creative process is clear.  Over and abovve that, universities also have  responsiblilities to society more broadly.  One of those responsibilities is to reflect that wider society.   Diversifying the professoriate  is a project which calls for a new intentionality in helping to hire and retain faculty of color.  That intentionality will mean taking actions in several ways. This particular effort involved organizing and hosting a workshop - led and organized by graduate stdents of color - within a meeting of a leading professional association. The workshop opened the discussion of how one discipline - politcal science - may begin to pursue that overall goal.  Issues and topics were surfaced that should assist departments as they seek to make progress on that overall goal.

For example, the workshop identified the importance of pipeline issues and the relevance of recruiting to graduate education. It discussed the value of affinity groups (caucuses and listservs) in publicizing positions and providing mentoring institutions. And it emphasized the value in seeking diversified short lists.

One issue surfaced within the workshop was a reminder that many faculty and graduate students of color are first generation college grads and graduate schools attendees.  Sensitivity to this point places a greater emphasis on - and reward from - good mentoring.
